D7C82EEC12A44A31A2C21FCED976A9D4.description: Natural objects exist from the very small to the immensely large. (5-ESS1-1)

A9BD90C3760D43F49236EBC86F95BA2C.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified and used to explain change. (5-PS2- 1)

19D6C39634B843858FCBEB207517EEF0.description: Similarities and differences in patterns can be used to sort, classify, communicate and analyze simple rates of change for natural phenomena. (5-ESS1-2)

700C8574494044F9B89236E66D063830.description: The orbits of Earth around the sun and of the moon around Earth, together with the rotation of Earth about an axis between its North and South poles, cause observable patterns. These include day and night; daily changes in the length and direction of shadows; and different positions of the sun, moon, and stars at different times of the day, month, and year. (5-ESS1-2)

7DC41EDB0971417EABA7BA46F76082C9.description: ESS1.B: Earth and the Solar System

2E8CC4991B4D421F8478B4A1D46E7BDF.description: The sun is a star that appears larger and brighter than other stars because it is closer. Stars range greatly in their distance from Earth. (5-ESS1-1)

35A699DC3F39410FB30829F48C95DB08.description: ESS1.A: The Universe and Its Stars

CCDA939B95EB4639B3F86B3F5CADE1F8.description: The gravitational force of Earth acting on an object near Earth’s surface pulls that object toward the planet’s center. (5-PS2-1)

2923C9D0762A4AA7BA04104F30911257.description: Support an argument with evidence, data, or a model. (5-PS2-1),(5-ESS1-1)

B10825D10E2143CBBAB8BE526B393690.description: Represent data in graphical displays (bar graphs, pictographs and/or pie charts) to reveal patterns that indicate relationships. (5-ESS1-2)

0D1DAFFEE240428D9483361C7E5CD10D.description: Represent data in graphical displays to reveal patterns of daily changes in length and direction of shadows, day and night, and the seasonal appearance of some stars in the night sky.

28FA5886AA4446848F862AB6396BBDFF.description: Support an argument that differences in the apparent brightness of the Sun compared to other stars is due to their relative distances from Earth.

614A6D3F9B064F0B9616D73F9B5059A1.description: Support an argument that the gravitational force exerted by Earth on objects is directed down.

745A51C6ED9143179D0AA5B502F1F38F.description: 5. Space Systems: Stars and the Solar System

C2A27023F255484099AFCEBD4E1B1A97.description: Science findings are limited to questions that can be answered with empirical evidence. (5-ESS3-1)

A8FC98B8384C4B05AD2A8C0320BC329A.description: Science Addresses Questions About the Natural and Material World

FC5809988A514052BF16B1F9FFA0BE82.description: A system can be described in terms of its components and their interactions. (5-ESS2-1),(5-ESS3-1)

1D1BC4E2FD704CA295DF9E1C5B90DDF6.description: Standard units are used to measure and describe physical quantities such as weight, and volume. (5- ESS2-2)

0C86DE245E2A4E3AA8A9138E96ED7CDC.description: Human activities in agriculture, industry, and everyday life have had major effects on the land, vegetation, streams, ocean, air, and even outer space. But individuals and communities are doing things to help protect Earth’s resources and environments. (5-ESS3-1)

48D806556CC843DDACFC364C6A05D4FD.description: ESS3.C: Human Impacts on Earth Systems

0526B936913A47F499F715C6EEF53537.description: Nearly all of Earth’s available water is in the ocean. Most fresh water is in glaciers or underground; only a tiny fraction is in streams, lakes, wetlands, and the atmosphere. (5- ESS2-2)

E1032F2C5AAA43CDB4F70DB8C07A1574.description: ESS2.C: The Roles of Water in Earth's Surface Processes

A986D99545194DB985329AC747E2D2A9.description: Earth’s major systems are the geosphere (solid and molten rock, soil, and sediments), the hydrosphere (water and ice), the atmosphere (air), and the biosphere (living things, including humans). These systems interact in multiple ways to affect Earth’s surface materials and processes. The ocean supports a variety of ecosystems and organisms, shapes landforms, and influences climate. Winds and clouds in the atmosphere interact with the landforms to determine patterns of weather. (5-ESS2-1)

B943BD27124E4F349F6DB46F10C45803.description: Obtain and combine information from books and/or other reliable media to explain phenomena or solutions to a design problem. (5-ESS3-1)

84E149661DF345D88759D975824F6070.description: Describe and graph quantities such as area and volume to address scientific questions. (5-ESS2-2)

4849EFD8233240C183FE9E7395D1104F.description: Develop a model using an example to describe a scientific principle. (5-ESS2-1)

A9ABD49EE1124A76845C3CE20CF8F138.description: Obtain and combine information about ways individual communities use science ideas to protect Earth’s resources and environment.

40D449EE10834AF5BB338E197A9B9F86.description: Describe and graph the amounts of salt water and fresh water in various reservoirs to provide evidence about the distribution of water on Earth.

D4E7AADA296843E9A3635BB02A6DF372.description: Develop a model using an example to describe ways the geosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere, and/or atmosphere interact

50169BD02BCD4A1EB9DD94FEEFC06398.description: Energy can be transferred in various ways and between objects. (5-PS3-1)

B34F080DCC564069BA7107DF021B7004.description: Matter is transported into, out of, and within systems. (5-LS1-1)

32D034A4C44E4119A68D156C801B8E19.description: A system can be described in terms of its components and their interactions. (5-LS2- 1)

5512C141CBDE4DDEADA411CBD3E1D500.description: Matter cycles between the air and soil and among plants, animals, and microbes as these organisms live and die. Organisms obtain gases, and water, from the environment, and release waste matter (gas, liquid, or solid) back into the environment. (5-LS2-1)

241B4B602C7E4CFD9B49EB16F3CE163E.description: LS2.B: Cycle of Matter and Energy Transfer in Ecosystems

05EF5E7C9F2B467088063628D87D0B40.description: The food of almost any kind of animal can be traced back to plants. Organisms are related in food webs in which some animals eat plants for food and other animals eat the animals that eat plants. Some organisms, such as fungi and bacteria, break down dead organisms (both plants or plants’ parts and animals) and therefore operate as “decomposers.” Decomposition eventually restores (recycles) some materials back to the soil. Organisms can survive only in environments in which their particular needs are met. A healthy ecosystem is one in which multiple species of different types are each able to meet their needs in a relatively stable web of life. Newly introduced species can damage the balance of an ecosystem. (5-LS2-1)

640EDE14BFF942EE808E63E02C25DE03.description: Plants acquire their material for growth chiefly from air and water. (5-LS1-1)

12893A4D566840CDAE6F71AEB8DD99BB.description: Food provides animals with the materials they need for body repair and growth and the energy they need to maintain body warmth and for motion. (secondary to 5-PS3-1)

BF82395C40E94510B93B18A7E658243A.description: LS1.C: Organization for Matter and Energy Flow in Organisms

5BCCF38AF73A499FB59A19873D7EF8AE.description: The energy released [from] food was once energy from the sun that was captured by plants in the chemical process that forms plant matter (from air and water). (5-PS3-1)

024A8BE132FC4649BE3137687BAF0D5A.description: PS3.D: Energy in Chemical Processes and Everyday Life

F251DCA9BF984E2F889C44F60B386925.description: Science explanations describe the mechanisms for natural events. (5-LS2-1)

8A84733063E949EE80A76A9FCC4F9381.description: Science Models, Laws, Mechanisms, and Theories Explain Natural Phenomena

30313E3DBBF248BFB32893918BE5E208.description: Support an argument with evidence, data, or a model. (5-LS1-1)

D2AAFCFEA56A41B89FE4A4ED92C01ABE.description: Develop a model to describe phenomena. (5-LS2-1)

E12A86EFD05E42238FE2CD2088C38972.description: Develop a model to describe the movement of matter among plants (producers), animals (consumers), decomposers, and the environment.

3D46511174874D36A25F600CC4DD42D5.description: Support an argument that plants get the materials they need for growth chiefly from air and water.

7D1509D08D3C47FCB9BC4C7186867F00.description: Use models to describe that energy in animals’ food (used for body repair, growth, motion, and to maintain body warmth) was once energy from the Sun.

89FDD1846EA541109756996B3C88E68D.description: 5. Matter and Energy in Organisms and Ecosystems

026C3AD41A864457B4BA3C7D038F2B53.description: Science assumes consistent patterns in natural systems. (5-PS1-2)

78E7005208534D4B96DD32A549CF40B9.description: Scientific Knowledge Assumes an Order and Consistency in Natural Systems

D3F97477D081434A9E22FA60E134237D.description: Standard units are used to measure and describe physical quantities such as weight, time, temperature, and volume. (5-PS1-2),(5- PS1-3)

7597C0C66D5D4E9097AEC77F4B3E269B.description: Natural objects exist from the very small to the immensely large. (5-PS1-1)

76CC070E19C94C398C9FE3421059155A.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified, tested, and used to explain change. (5-PS1-4)

2DF608BE1A8B4E6DBBC8C68E61A615B5.description: No matter what reaction or change in properties occurs, the total weight of the substances does not change. (Boundary: Mass and weight are not distinguished at this grade level.) (5- PS1-2)

DA67119757D047EEAE08D5D314AA770C.description: When two or more different substances are mixed, a new substance with different properties may be formed. (5-PS1-4)

31267FEB8BFA4ADF9F360A21870A393B.description: Measurements of a variety of properties can be used to identify materials. (Boundary: At this grade level, mass and weight are not distinguished, and no attempt is made to define the unseen particles or explain the atomic-scale mechanism of evaporation and condensation.) (5-PS1-3)

25789D5CED2F4AF7AAC357CF29C7CF9C.description: (NYSED) The total amount of matter is conserved when it changes form, even in transitions in which it seems to vanish. (5-PS1-2)

F7AE800770F44E2C8A65FBA5E4EC846B.description: Matter of any type can be subdivided into particles that are too small to see, but even then the matter still exists and can be detected by other means. A model showing that gases are made from matter particles that are too small to see and are moving freely around in space can explain many observations, including the inflation and shape of a balloon and the effects of air on larger particles or objects. (5-PS1-1)

DA14A6AE9F534D01A4B87BD6BF309D8B.description: PS1.A: Structure and Properties of Matter

40B81E6A80014975918927CA9D358D3E.description: Measure and graph quantities such as weight to address scientific and engineering questions and problems. (5-PS1-2)

08F59DC78D6C45199F7E261C4B1CD137.description: Make observations and measurements to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence for an explanation of a phenomenon. (5-PS1-3)

83DBACF409B742D899D68D748BA08974.description: Conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence, using fair tests in which variables are controlled and the number of trials considered. (5-PS1-4)

2333725D648240F6AFAB29D14DA20DBC.description: Develop a model to describe phenomena. (5- PS1-1)

BE704018C48F4833B089296538CA19CF.description: Conduct an investigation to determine whether the mixing of two or more substances results in new substances

0217D7D75CA04416A4E8A4060144F3E5.description: Make observations and measurements to identify materials based on their properties.

185C2AE998294427A34F5919DC557BA0.description: Measure and graph quantities to provide evidence that regardless of the type of change that occurs when heating, cooling, or mixing substances the total amount of matter is conserved.

BDFE6B60C3E0453EAF95783AE227378D.description: Develop a model to describe that matter is made of particles too small to be seen.

3A452D7F19FF4D3D8861497E042E3A4D.description: Engineers improve existing technologies or develop new ones to increase their benefits, decrease known risks, and meet societal demands. (3-5-ETS1-2)

FAFD6F7AA8D74304A3E330A11502502D.description: People’s needs and wants change over time, as do their demands for new and improved technologies. (3-5-ETS1-1)

9D0E3B4E039645C78D9A6DD65ED58A67.description: Influence of Science, Engineering, and Technology on Society and the Natural World

D6B84E78020045C884B7E8D6ADBFCE7D.description: Different solutions need to be tested in order to determine which of them best solves the problem, given the criteria and the constraints. (3-5-ETS1-3)

D27603A691E24277A756B394D0C148D3.description: Tests are often designed to identify failure points or difficulties, which suggest the elements of the design that need to be improved. (3-5-ETS1-3)

9A8BBE05971E4CD18DDEF58F1C3611F1.description: At whatever stage, communicating with peers about proposed solutions is an important part of the design process, and shared ideas can lead to improved designs. (3-5-ETS1-2)

D9EF4A977030415695A959550BA4DF87.description: Research on a problem should be carried out before beginning to design a solution. Testing a solution involves investigating how well it performs under a range of likely conditions. (3-5-ETS1-2)

80E5C833768C468BA2E4F619EE581BDD.description: Possible solutions to a problem are limited by available materials and resources (constraints). The success of a designed solution is determined by considering the desired features of a solution (criteria). Different proposals for solutions can be compared on the basis of how well each one meets the specified criteria for success or how well each takes the constraints into account. (3-5-ETS1-1)

0E5240AFE6384F3EA64BDDFC57ECF976.description: ETS1.A: Defining and Delimiting Engineering Problems

ECF2BE5612A347ED8082CC1535F7712C.description: Generate and compare multiple solutions to a problem based on how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the design problem. (3-5-ETS1- 2)

DD1C05B8877445B9B6D615089D1F4986.description: Plan and conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence, using fair tests in which variables are controlled and the number of trials considered. (3-5-ETS1-3)

D14E2700156E4A678EBD5893695C0DB9.description: Define a simple design problem that can be solved through the development of an object, tool, process, or system and includes several criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost. (3-5- ETS1-1)

B440442AEEF1469BBD024375AE6A4EE4.description: Plan and carry out fair tests in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that can be improved.

25181A19B7CF4018BDDA4A100F274818.description: Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

5247A15AADB34B7EA8CDDA1158C9F1CE.description: Define a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost.

B3EA2AA1A00247D8973831B867668EAB.description: NY State State Grade 4 Science Standards
